A message from our friends at MapleGOOD:

MapleGOOD has adopted a new initiative with the start of the school year and we want to spread the word! Our Student and Family Support Project will be offering FREE community support to K-12 students in Maplewood and Richmond Heights. If a child in your care is living or receiving care in the 63143 or 63117 zip codes (regardless of which school they attend), please complete an intake form at maplegood.org/sfs to help us understand their needs. More info can be found below on our flyer.

Also, if you'd like to be a volunteer for this special project, please also complete the intake form and let us know how you would like to help. We will need a lot of support to give alot of support so please join us and please share this with others!

Maplewood Transit Stop Transformation Project Complete, Open to the Public.

Citizens for Modern Transit and AARP in St. Louis have been working to activate the Maplewood MetroBus Stop located at the southwest corner of Manchester Rd. and Marshall Ave. in partnership with the City of Maplewood, Citizens National Bank and KABOOM!, a national non-profit that partners with communities to expand play opportunities. CMT included MRH Middle School students in the planning process, soliciting their input on its design. The project, known as the “Transit Stop Transformation Project,” is now complete and open to the public. Residents can take advantage of the newly renovated space – located adjacent to the Citizens National Bank parklet – and see firsthand how it encourages active play, cultivates community and increases transit use. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xhsPrOe-RqM&feature=youtu.be

The MRH School Board's commitment to Equity in Education continues with this exciting NEW opportunity for our families.

Our partners at the Midwest and Plains Equity Assistance Center have created a series of virtual roundtables throughout June. These sessions are dynamic, online learning experiences aimed at providing an opportunity for parents/caregivers with different backgrounds (i.e. families of color, families with varied religious backgrounds, families with children with disabilities, families from disinvested communities, non-traditional families) to talk with and ask questions of an expert in family and community supports, and in home and school partnership. In this series, families from various backgrounds will engage in discussion with each other and a featured expert, who is also a parent/caregiver, with the aim of sharing ideas and resources related to supporting students and families during the COVID-19 pandemic.

For information on how to participate, go to the MRH website: https://www.mrhschools.net/news/latest-headlines/2020/05/20/1628

Tomorrow, Thursday April 16, marks the kickoff of a new, expanded service for MRH families by Weekend on Wheels. WOW is the donations-based food pantry operated by the Maplewood Richmond Heights School District. Once weekly on Thursdays, WOW will provide food bags to any MRH student or family who is in need of nutritional support. The bags will be available for pickup beginning April 16 from 10am-1pm outside the MRH Research & Design Center, 7539 Manchester Road, Maplewood, MO., 63143. Please remain in your vehicle while MRH food service employees -- using strict health and safety protocols -- bring the bags to you. We will provide one bag per client per week for the remainder of the academic school year. The contents of the food bags will vary from week to week. On the 16th, the bags will contain snack items; on the 23rd, they will contain meal starters and sides. If you have questions or need additional information, contact kat.norton@mrhschools.net

Special thanks to MRH Superintendent Dr. Karen Hall and her son Nathan for sorting and bagging tomorrow's food items.

Maplewood Richmond Heights High School
April 13 at 9:03 AM ·

Get set for your heartstrings to get tugged, after reading this note from ECC teacher Heather Bailey:

"I came across this flag in my basement. It's a symbol of a classroom community of first graders I had in 2008. That year, as we learned about government, the class decided we could form our own government. We started by designing this flag to represent ourselves. We moved onto creating a mission, laws, and consequences. (On the back of the flag, there's even a pocket containing our government handbook.)
Remembering the ideals of these young seven year olds, fills me with hope for our nation's future. I know these young adults will continue to care for others as they change the world. I'm sorry the world isn't as we thought it would be for your senior year, but I'm so thankful it's you who is graduating. Our world needs you, and we've been waiting a very long time. Congratulations on all of your hard work. I'm proud of you and who you've become.
Love,
Mrs. Bailey
P.S. I'd love to see pictures of you in the comments.
